citations.narrative:
The acquisition record (cage card) for 7 un-weaned puppies born to Jazzy on 7/23/2025 was incomplete. The puppies
were not listed individually on the cage card or an APHIS 7005 form (Record of Acquisition of Dogs and Cats). The official
birth record (cage card) made available did not include the sex, or color and distinctive markings of each puppy born.
Accurate record keeping is essential so that APHIS inspectors can adequately identify the dogs and their acquisition and
disposition, for the purposes of tracking the dogs health and wellbeing.
Each dealer shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the information concerning
each dog purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, or which is transported, sold, or otherwise disposed of by that
dealer. The records shall include any offspring born to any animal while in his or her control. Such records shall
encompass, among other requirements, a description of each dog that includes the sex and the color and any distinctive
markings.
To be corrected by 8/27/2025.

Heartworm prevention was not administered to all the adult dogs on a monthly basis as required by the program of
Veterinary Care and as acknowledged by the licensee. In the given month, the following dogs did not receive a monthly
dose of ivermectin (for heartworm prevention):
1) In May of 2025: Lacy, Lassie, Cheyenne, Kelly, Tara, Nala, Brianna, and Tennley;
2) In June of 2025: Zena, Jr. Duke, Cheyenne, Bruno, Diesel, Simba, Opal, Ling, Luli, Nala, Waldo King, Brianna, Kelly,
Tina, Tara, Tennley, Yoshi, Oscar, Jemma, and Jazzy;
3) In July of 2025: Zena, Lacy, Lassie, Jr. Duke, Cheyenne, Bruno, Diesel, Simba, Opal, Ling, Luli, Nala, Waldo King,
Brianna, Diamond, Ronnie, Tina, Tara, Tennley, Yogi, Yoshi, Oscar, Jemma, and Jazzy.
Failure to implement the preventative treatments prescribed in the program of veterinary care, by the attending
veterinarian, can lead to the development of diseases in the dogs that cause illness, discomfort, or death.
The licensee must follow the program of veterinary care for dogs that is developed, documented, and signed by the
attending veterinarian. This includes administering the prescribed preventive treatments for contagious and deadly
diseases, parasites, and other pests (such as rabies, parvovirus, distemper, fleas, worms, coccidia, giardia, and
heartworm, etc.), in accordance with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian.
To be corrected by 8/27/2025.

Medical records for three litters of puppies (born 5/24/2025, 6/8/2025, & 7/2/2025) were incomplete. The medical records
did not record the administration of vaccinations and anti-parasitic medications to these three litters of puppies in
accordance with the Program of Veterinary Care; though, the license indicated the medications were given. The license
pre-populates medical records for puppies with the dates various medications are to be given. Then the license places a
check mark by the pre-populated administration dates, to designate that the medications were administered. However, the
records of the administration of medications to puppies was not documented as follows:
1) For the puppies born on 5/24/2025, administration of vaccinations and antiparasitic drugs was not recorded with check
marks for week 8 (starting on 7/19/2025).
2) For the puppies born on 6/8/2025, administration of vaccinations and antiparasitic drugs was not recorded with check
marks for week 6 (starting on 7/20/2025) or week 8 (starting on 8/3/2025).
3) For the puppies born on 7/2/2025, administration of vaccinations and antiparasitic drugs was not recorded with check
marks for week 6 (starting on 8/13/2025).
Incomplete medical records prevent APHIS officials from verifying that treatments and preventive medications important
to the health and wellbeing of the animals are being administered as directed by the attending veterinarian.
Medical records for dogs must include the names of all vaccine and treatments administered and clearly identify the dates
of administration.
To be corrected by 8/17/2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.75(a)(1)(vii) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The acquisition record (cage card) for 7 un-weaned puppies born to Jazzy on 7/23/2025 was incomplete. The puppies 
were not listed individually on the cage card or an APHIS 7005 form (Record of Acquisition of Dogs and Cats). The official 
birth record (cage card) made available did not include the sex, or color and distinctive markings of each puppy born. 
 
Accurate record keeping is essential so that APHIS inspectors can adequately identify the dogs and their acquisition and 
disposition, for the purposes of tracking the dogs health and wellbeing. 
 
Each dealer shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the information concerning 
each dog purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, or which is transported, sold, or otherwise disposed of by that 
dealer. The records shall include any offspring born to any animal while in his or her control. Such records shall 
encompass, among other requirements, a description of each dog that includes the sex and the color and any distinctive 
markings. 
 
To be corrected by 8/27/2025. 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
Heartworm prevention was not administered to all the adult dogs on a monthly basis as required by the program of 
Veterinary Care and as acknowledged by the licensee. In the given month, the following dogs did not receive a monthly 
dose of ivermectin (for heartworm prevention): 
1) In May of 2025: Lacy, Lassie, Cheyenne, Kelly, Tara, Nala, Brianna, and Tennley;  
2) In June of 2025: Zena, Jr. Duke, Cheyenne, Bruno, Diesel, Simba, Opal, Ling, Luli, Nala, Waldo King, Brianna, Kelly, 
Tina, Tara, Tennley, Yoshi, Oscar, Jemma, and Jazzy; 
3) In July of 2025: Zena, Lacy, Lassie, Jr. Duke, Cheyenne, Bruno, Diesel, Simba, Opal, Ling, Luli, Nala, Waldo King, 
Brianna, Diamond, Ronnie, Tina, Tara, Tennley, Yogi, Yoshi, Oscar, Jemma, and Jazzy. 
 
Failure to implement the preventative treatments prescribed in the program of veterinary care, by the attending 
veterinarian, can lead to the development of diseases in the dogs that cause illness, discomfort, or death.

The licensee must follow the program of veterinary care for dogs that is developed, documented, and signed by the 
attending veterinarian. This includes administering the prescribed preventive treatments for contagious and deadly 
diseases, parasites, and other pests (such as rabies, parvovirus, distemper, fleas, worms, coccidia, giardia, and 
heartworm, etc.), in accordance with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian. 
 
To be corrected by 8/27/2025. 
3.13(b)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
Medical records for three litters of puppies (born 5/24/2025, 6/8/2025, & 7/2/2025) were incomplete. The medical records 
did not record the administration of vaccinations and anti-parasitic medications to these three litters of puppies in 
accordance with the Program of Veterinary Care; though, the license indicated the medications were given. The license 
pre-populates medical records for puppies with the dates various medications are to be given. Then the license places a 
check mark by the pre-populated administration dates, to designate that the medications were administered. However, the 
records of the administration of medications to puppies was not documented as follows: 
1) For the puppies born on 5/24/2025, administration of vaccinations and antiparasitic drugs was not recorded with check 
marks for week 8 (starting on 7/19/2025). 
2) For the puppies born on 6/8/2025, administration of vaccinations and antiparasitic drugs was not recorded with check 
marks for week 6 (starting on 7/20/2025) or week 8 (starting on 8/3/2025). 
3) For the puppies born on 7/2/2025, administration of vaccinations and antiparasitic drugs was not recorded with check 
marks for week 6 (starting on 8/13/2025). 
 
Incomplete medical records prevent APHIS officials from verifying that treatments and preventive medications important 
to the health and wellbeing of the animals are being administered as directed by the attending veterinarian. 
 
Medical records for dogs must include the names of all vaccine and treatments administered and clearly identify the dates 
of administration. 
 
To be corrected by 8/17/2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
